text:
I've frequently compiled / installed Apache on plenty of different Hardware / OS
combinations and never come across this before, so I thought I'd sumbit it to
help out, although I highly doubt it's a major issue.

When running configure on an Apache 2.2.3 release, I decided (for the hell of
it) to link it against my pre-installed PCRE library (in /usr/local, version
6.7) and configure fails stating:

configure: error: Size of "void *" is less than size of "long"

Well, sadly, that's just not true.  On my architecture, a void pointer is 4
bytes, and so is a long.  I've confirmed this just to make certain:

enoch:~$ cat test.c
#include <stdio.h>

int main(){
        printf("Sizeof void *: %d\nSizeof long: %d\n",sizeof(void *), sizeof(long));
        return 0;
}
enoch:~$ gcc -o test.run test.c
enoch:~$ ./test.run
Sizeof void *: 4
Sizeof long: 4


Okay, so that's that.  Take out the configure option "--with-pcre=/usr/local"
and it configures, compiles and installs just fine.

Just thought I'd let you know!
creator: untilzero@gmail.com

text:
The real error is:

./conftest: error while loading shared libraries: libpcre.so.0: cannot open
shared object file: No such file or directory

you need to either add /usr/local/lib to /etc/ld.so.conf or set LD_LIBRARY_PATH
or whatever, to allow the runtime linker to find PCRE.

creator: tom.lake@glossa.co.uk
text: This can happen if the PCRE library is not on the LD_LIBRARY_PATH. This particular test - for void pointer length - is the first to fail and gives an incorrect indication that sizeof(void*) < sizeof(long) - which is generally completely misleading.
